label: California establishes Structural Engineer (SE) title act.
Notes: California becomes the first state to create a distinct SE license under the Civil Engineers Act.

label: California Professional Engineers Act separates CE and SE practice scopes.
Notes: Structural Engineers are required for complex structures; aligns with state seismic design focus.

label: NCEES introduces Structural I and Structural II exams.
Code: UBC 1994/1997, AISC ASD 9th Ed, ACI 318, NDS (wood)
Format:
SE I: Multiple choice
SE II: Essay problems
Notes: Two-tier national exam system; Structural II recognized by California for SE comity applicants. SE I was 4 hours, SE II was 8 hours. Design primarily used Allowable Stress Design (ASD) methods.

label: Exam content updated.
Format:
SE I: Multiple choice
SE II: Essay problems
Notes: Incorporated seismic provisions from regional codes transitioning to national standards.

label: NCEES updates design standards references.
Format:
SE I: Multiple choice
SE II: Essay problems
Notes: Marks shift from regional (UBC) to national building codes (IBC).

label: Exam references updated for mid-cycle codes.
Format:
SE I: Multiple choice
SE II: Essay problems
Notes: Significant wind provision changes in ASCE 7-05. Steel design transitioned to include LRFD methods alongside ASD.

label: Exam references updated for mid-cycle codes.
Format:
SE I: Multiple choice
SE II: Essay problems
Notes: Significant wind provision changes in ASCE 7-05. Steel design transitioned to include LRFD methods alongside ASD.

label: NCEES launches 16-hour Structural Engineering Exam.
Format:
Breadth: Multiple choice (40 questions)
Depth: Essay problems (4-6 per section)
Notes: Replaces SE I/II with two 8-hour components (Vertical and Lateral). Each component has a 4-hour breadth section and 4-hour depth section. Hand calculations required for depth problems.

label: Exam specifications revised.
Format:
Breadth: Multiple choice (40 questions)
Depth: Essay problems (4-6 per section)
Notes: Updated lateral load procedures and concrete detailing requirements. Depth problems remained hand-calculated with full documentation.

label: Minor specification updates.
Format:
Breadth: Multiple choice (40 questions)
Depth: Essay problems (4-6 per section)
Notes: Revisions aligned with adoption of updated building codes in most U.S. jurisdictions.

label: Final pencil-and-paper SE exam (October 2023).
Format:
Breadth: Multiple choice (40 questions)
Depth: Essay problems (4-6 per section)
Notes: Last administration before transition to computer-based testing (CBT). Required physical reference materials (books, codes).

label: NCEES transitions SE exam to CBT format (April 2024).
Format:
Breadth: 55 multiple choice (45 scored, 10 pretest)
Depth: 60 questions (40 scored, 20 pretest) in 5 scenarios
Notes: Four separate modules: Vertical Breadth (6 hrs), Vertical Depth (5.5 hrs), Lateral Breadth (6 hrs), Lateral Depth (5.5 hrs). Total exam time is 23 hours across 4 tests. Breadth sections administered year-round; depth sections twice per year (April/October). Digital reference handbook provided. Depth sections are scenario-based with alternative item types (fill-in, point-and-click). No more hand-written essay solutions.
